title: Why is talking in person and online 'different'? - Quora

response.answer_text: There’s a lot more information being conveyed during an in-person conversation versus online. There’s a lot more than I’m going to list here, but to give you a high level: Body LanguageFacial ExpressionTone of voiceVoice inflectionAll of these are easy to pick up on when you’re face to face with someone, but trying to get them across through text is not very easy. A single statement could have many meanings if the other person could only hear your tone and inflection, but through chat it’s really up to them to interpret. There’s also basically no risk in completely misrepresenting yourself online; just think about the number of times people add smiley face emoji’s, LOLs or HAHAHAs when they’re not really laughing or smiling. How would the other person even know that you’ve maintained the same stoic face while endlessly bombarding them with suggestions that you’re having the time of your life? In an online conversation, it’s more about presenting yourself a certain way than conveying your true emotions. But when you see that person in public and they’re not laughing after everything you say, it could come as quite the surprise. It also takes more skill to have an in-person conversation; you have to be on the spot, you don’t get so much time to sit back and ponder the perfect unless you don’t mind being awkward. Imagine telling someone they’re pretty online vs in-person: In-person you’re trying to sound confident but not too forward, or at the very minimum you want it to come out at the right time where she’s in a similar emotional state. If she reacts poorly, you’ve gotten yourself in an awkward situation that you can’t really just walk away from; it’s not easy for most people to just brush off rejection and move on, so maybe you refrain from saying it all together and just wait for a better moment. There’s a lot more risk to messing up in-person.Online you can say whatever you want, and if you get a bad reaction you can immediately cut off all communication with that person with no repercussions. Now it’s much easier to give a compliment, and if they already like you they’ll probably interpret it however sounds good to them (even if it would have sounded awkward coming from your mouth). Coming out of your mouth the words may sound shaky and awkward, but online the words are just as confident no matter who’s typing them.

Talking online and talking in person is different because 90% of our communication is non-verbal. When you talk to someone online, you only have their words on a screen and a photo to go by. (This, I think, is part of the reason why emoji is such a fast growing language -because devs are trying to create viable virtual substitutes for a range of things you communicate non-verbally in person.) Granted, written words can also tell you a lot about a person, but they can’t replace things like: a) eye contact, or lack thereof b) the nuances of facial expressions c) body posture d) tone, volume, pitch, and hue of voice e) hand gestures and so on. All these elements of non-verbal communication help you formulate a more complete picture of what the person you’re talking to is thinking or feeling, how focused they are on what you’re telling them, whether you’re annoying them etc. Tone is notoriously hard to communicate online, which is also why a lot of people get misunderstood if, for example, they use short sentences. Of course, different people have different preferences in terms of modes of communication. A lot of people feel more comfortable talking online, because talking online helps them feel less self-conscious, freer to express themselves, etc. A lot of people, for example, hate talking on the phone. It really depends on what you’re used to, and how good you are at picking up social cues, both online and in person. Those are my thoughts anyway :) (…smiley face to indicate that even though I might be coming across as an arrogant know-it-all, if we were having this conversation in person I would smile a lot to let you know that I’m open to other opinions.) ;)
